greeting: Hi {{patient_name}}! Welcome to egg freezing journey ðŸ¥šâ„ï¸
context: You're considering freezing your eggs - smart decision!
explanation: Egg freezing preserves YOUR eggs at current age/quality for future use. Best before age 35 (egg quality peaks). Process: Stimulation (10-14 days) â†’ Retrieval â†’ Freeze. Use them later for IVF when you're ready for baby. No expiration date!
next_steps: {{plan}} - AMH + baseline scan to assess reserve â†’ Stimulation protocol design â†’ Financial planning (â‚¹1.5-2L per cycle) â†’ Timeline discussion
reassurance: Freezing eggs = buying time without compromising fertility! Whether for career, health, or not finding partner yet - you're taking control of your future. Empowering! ðŸ’ª
call_to_action: Schedule AMH test + scan on Day 2-3 of next period. Bring partner/family to next consult if helpful. Questions? WhatsApp anytime!

greeting: Hi {{patient_name}}, thank you for coming in to discuss egg freezing.
context: Let me walk you through what egg freezing entails and whether it's right for you.
explanation: [CLEAR EXPLANATION] Egg freezing is essentially the first half of IVF - we stimulate your ovaries with hormones to grow multiple eggs, retrieve them through a minor procedure, and then freeze them using a flash-freezing technique called vitrification. The eggs stay frozen indefinitely - 10 years, 20 years, as long as needed. When you're ready to have a baby, we thaw the eggs, fertilize them with sperm, grow embryos, and transfer one to your uterus. [PAUSE] The key is to freeze eggs while you're young - ideally under 35 - because egg quality declines with age. If you freeze at 32 and use them at 40, those are still 32-year-old eggs, not 40-year-old eggs.
next_steps: Here's what we need to do next: First, blood test for AMH to check your ovarian reserve - how many eggs you have. Second, a baseline ultrasound to count your follicles. This tells us how many eggs we might get per cycle. Based on your age {{patient_age}}, I'd recommend freezing {{recommended_egg_count}} eggs total for a good chance of future pregnancy. That might mean {{cycle_count}} retrieval cycles.
reassurance: [EMPATHY] I know this feels like a big decision - you're planning for a future baby that might not exist yet. But many of my patients say freezing eggs gave them peace of mind. It removes the biological clock pressure. You can focus on career, travel, finding the right partner - whatever you need - knowing your fertility is preserved.
call_to_action: Think it over, discuss with family if that helps. No rush on the decision, but the sooner you freeze, the better the egg quality. When you're ready, we'll schedule the AMH test and get started.
contact_info: Any questions for me now? [WAIT] You can reach me at {{clinic_phone}} anytime.

eventName: AMH Result - Good Reserve for Egg Freezing
context: Your AMH is {{amh_value}} ng/mL - great reserve for your age!
explanation: At age {{patient_age}}, AMH {{amh_value}} means you have good egg quantity. Expected retrieval: {{estimated_eggs}} eggs per cycle. For optimal future success, aim to freeze {{target_egg_count}} eggs total = {{cycle_count}} cycle(s).
next_steps: Baseline scan Day 2-3 of next period â†’ Start stimulation Day 2 â†’ Retrieval ~Day 13 â†’ Freeze â†’ Repeat if needed for second cycle
reassurance: Your numbers look great! You're in an excellent position to bank enough eggs for future. Starting soon maximizes quality while you're young! â°
call_to_action: Call on Day 1 of next period. We'll schedule baseline scan. Financial counseling available for multi-cycle packages (discounts!).

eventName: AMH Result - Low Reserve for Egg Freezing
greeting: Hi {{patient_name}}, it's Dr. {{doctor_name}}. I have your AMH results.
context: [GENTLE TONE] Your AMH came back at {{amh_value}}, which is lower than we'd like for your age.
explanation: [HONEST] AMH below 1.0 means diminished ovarian reserve - fewer eggs remaining. For egg freezing, this presents a challenge. In one cycle, we might only retrieve {{estimated_eggs}} eggs, and not all will be mature. To bank a reasonable number like {{target_egg_count}} eggs, you'd likely need {{cycle_count}} cycles, which gets expensive. [PAUSE]
next_steps: [OPTIONS] Here are your options: 1) Proceed with egg freezing anyway - at least freeze what you can. 2) Aggressively stimulate and do back-to-back cycles quickly. 3) Consider that if you're planning to have a baby in the next 2-3 years anyway, it might make more sense to try naturally or do IVF now rather than freeze. 4) Accept that egg freezing may not be cost-effective and focus on other paths like donor eggs in future if needed.
reassurance: [EMPATHY] I'm sorry this isn't the news you were hoping for. Low AMH at {{patient_age}} isn't uncommon, but it does mean your biological clock is ticking faster. The good news is AMH doesn't predict egg QUALITY, only quantity. You might get fewer eggs, but they could still be good quality.
call_to_action: Take time to think about what makes sense for you - financially and life-planning wise. We can move forward with freezing if you want, but I want you to have realistic expectations about the numbers.
contact_info: Let's schedule a follow-up call to discuss. No pressure. Call me at {{clinic_phone}} when you've had time to process.

explanation: Out of {{total_eggs}} eggs: {{mature_eggs}} are mature (MII - perfect for freezing!), {{mi_eggs}} are MI (almost mature), {{gv_eggs}} are GV (immature). We're freezing all {{mature_eggs}} mature eggs using vitrification. This is EXCELLENT for age {{patient_age}}!
next_steps: {{plan}} - Rest today. Light cramping/bloating normal. {{cycle_status}} - Target reached! Done freezing. OR Need {{additional_eggs}} more - schedule Cycle 2 in {{timeline}}
reassurance: {{mature_eggs}} frozen eggs = {{success_probability}}% chance of future baby! You've preserved your fertility beautifully! Every egg is a potential future child. ðŸŒŸ
call_to_action: Drink lots of water (OHSS prevention). No sex for 1 week. Period in ~2 weeks. Report severe bloating/pain. Celebrate this achievement! ðŸŽŠ

greeting: Hi {{patient_name}}, it's Dr. {{doctor_name}}. You're in recovery now, feeling okay?
context: [GENTLE] I wanted to go over the retrieval results with you.
explanation: [HONEST TONE] We retrieved {{total_eggs}} eggs total. Of those, {{mature_eggs}} were mature enough to freeze. [PAUSE] I know we were hoping for more based on the follicle count we saw on scans - there were {{follicle_count}} follicles. Sometimes not all follicles contain eggs, or some eggs are too immature. It's called 'empty follicle syndrome' when it's extreme, but in your case, it's just lower than expected.
next_steps: [CLEAR] So here's where we stand: You now have {{mature_eggs}} frozen eggs. To get to our target of {{target_egg_count}} eggs total, you'd need {{remaining_cycles}} more cycle(s). We can do another cycle as soon as your next period - your ovaries will be ready again. Or we can wait a few months if you want a break.
reassurance: [EMPATHY] I know this isn't the number you wanted to hear. But {{mature_eggs}} eggs is still valuable - it's not zero, and each one has potential. Some women get pregnant from just one or two frozen eggs. Quality matters more than quantity. Your eggs at age {{patient_age}} are still good quality.
call_to_action: For now, rest and recover. We'll wait for your period and review whether you want to do another cycle. No pressure either way - it's your decision based on finances, time, and emotional energy.
contact_info: Take care of yourself. Any questions as you recover, call the nurses at {{clinic_phone}}. We'll check in with you tomorrow.

eventName: Second Egg Freezing Cycle - Target Reached
context: Cycle 2 retrieval complete - you've hit your target!
explanation: Today: {{cycle2_eggs}} mature eggs frozen. TOTAL BANKED: {{total_mature_eggs}} frozen eggs ({{cycle1_eggs}} from Cycle 1 + {{cycle2_eggs}} from Cycle 2). This is the sweet spot for future success! ðŸŽ¯
next_steps: You're DONE with egg freezing! Eggs stored safely at -196Â°C in liquid nitrogen. Annual storage fee: {{storage_fee}}. No expiration - use anytime in next 10-20 years when ready!
reassurance: {{total_mature_eggs}} eggs = {{success_rate}}% chance of having at least one baby in future! You've invested in your fertility insurance. Future You will thank Present You! ðŸ’š
call_to_action: Rest, recover, celebrate! No more injections! Storage agreement will be mailed. Maintain contact info updates with clinic. Questions about future use? We're here!
contact_info: Congratulations on completing this journey! Dr. {{doctor_name}} | {{clinic_phone}}

eventName: Egg Freezing for Medical Reasons - Urgent
context: Before your {{treatment_type}} treatment, we need to freeze eggs NOW.
explanation: {{treatment_type}} (chemotherapy/radiation/surgery) will likely damage/remove ovaries. Freezing eggs BEFORE treatment preserves fertility. Timeline: Start injections ASAP â†’ Retrieval in 10-14 days â†’ Freeze â†’ Clear for oncology treatment by {{treatment_start_date}}.
next_steps: Emergency protocol: High-dose stimulation (compress timeline if needed). Coordinate with oncology team. Financial: Many insurance covers fertility preservation for medical reasons + nonprofits offer grants.
reassurance: I know cancer diagnosis is overwhelming + fertility feels secondary. But future fertility matters! We'll work FAST to preserve eggs before treatment. Many cancer survivors use frozen eggs to have babies later! ðŸ’ª
call_to_action: Start injections TODAY/TOMORROW. Compressed schedule - daily monitoring. Oncology aware of timeline. We'll get this done quickly!

eventName: Using Frozen Eggs - Thaw Cycle Consult
greeting: {{patient_name}}, ready to use your frozen eggs! ðŸ¥šâž¡ï¸ðŸ‘¶
context: You froze {{frozen_egg_count}} eggs in {{freeze_year}} - time to use them!
explanation: Process: 1) Thaw all eggs (survival rate ~90-95%). 2) Fertilize with {{sperm_source}} sperm via ICSI. 3) Grow embryos 5-6 days. 4) Transfer best embryo(s) OR freeze all embryos for FET. Expected: {{expected_embryos}} embryos from {{frozen_egg_count}} eggs.
next_steps: Husband sperm analysis (if using partner) â†’ Stimulation for you? NO! Just lining prep (estrogen). â†’ Thaw eggs on Day {{thaw_day}} â†’ Fertilization â†’ Transfer Day {{transfer_day}}
reassurance: Eggs frozen {{years_frozen}} years ago are just as good as fresh! Vitrification technology is amazing - eggs don't 'age' in freezer. This is why you froze them! ðŸŽ‰
call_to_action: Schedule Day 1 call next period. Coordinate sperm source. Excited to help you start your family NOW! Questions? WhatsApp!

explanation: Thawed {{total_thawed}} eggs. Survived: {{survived_eggs}} ({{survival_rate}}%!). Mature & ready for ICSI: {{mature_eggs}}. This is EXCELLENT survival! Normal is 85-95%.
next_steps: ICSI fertilization happening NOW with {{sperm_source}}. Fertilization report tomorrow (Day 1). Embryo updates Day 3 & Day 5. Transfer likely Day {{transfer_day}}.
reassurance: {{survived_eggs}} eggs survived = {{survived_eggs}} chances for embryos! Frozen eggs work just as well as fresh. You made the right choice years ago! ðŸ’š
call_to_action: Rest today. Wait for fertilization report tomorrow. Keep phone on - we'll call with updates! Stay hopeful! ðŸ¤ž

greeting: Hi {{patient_name}}, it's Dr. {{doctor_name}}. I need to discuss the thaw results with you.
context: [GENTLE TONE] We thawed your {{total_thawed}} frozen eggs this morning.
explanation: [HONEST] Unfortunately, the survival rate wasn't as good as we hoped. Only {{survived_eggs}} out of {{total_thawed}} eggs survived the thaw intact - that's {{survival_rate}}%. Typically we see 90-95% survival, so this is lower. [PAUSE] It's hard to say why - sometimes it's the freezing technique used years ago (older vitrification methods), sometimes it's just bad luck. The good news is the {{survived_eggs}} that did survive look healthy and we're proceeding with ICSI fertilization.
next_steps: [CLEAR] We're moving forward with the {{survived_eggs}} eggs. We'll fertilize them today and see how many become embryos. But I want to prepare you: with only {{survived_eggs}} eggs, we might get {{expected_embryos}} embryos. Depending on how this goes, you might want to consider: 1) Using all embryos from this batch first, or 2) If you have more frozen eggs, thawing another batch to increase the embryo pool.
reassurance: [EMPATHY] I know this isn't the news you wanted after waiting all these years to use your eggs. But please don't lose hope - it only takes one good embryo to make a baby. We've had patients get pregnant from one or two eggs. Let's see how fertilization goes tomorrow.
call_to_action: For now, there's nothing to do but wait. We'll call you tomorrow with the fertilization report. Try not to catastrophize - let's see what happens with these {{survived_eggs}} eggs first.
contact_info: I'm here for you. Call me anytime at {{clinic_phone}} if you need to talk.

context: Aapko PCOS hai - egg freezing ke liye special protocol chahiye.
explanation: PCOS = bahut saare follicles (high AMH {{amh_value}}). Achhi baat: Bahut eggs milenge! Buri baat: OHSS (over-stimulation) ka risk. Solution: Low-dose stimulation, GnRH antagonist protocol, Lupron trigger (not hCG).
next_steps: Metformin {{metformin_dose}} 1 month pehle se (insulin control). Low-dose gonadotropins (75-150 IU). Daily monitoring. Trigger with Lupron. Expected: {{expected_eggs}} eggs but SAFE!
reassurance: PCOS patients bahut achhe se eggs freeze kar sakte hain - high quantity! Bas carefully manage karna hota hai. Hum experts hain! ðŸ’ª
call_to_action: Metformin start karo aaj se. Weight loss bhi help karega (if BMI >25). Next period pe baseline. Questions? WhatsApp!

explanation: Per Cycle Cost: Medications {{medication_cost}}, Monitoring {{monitoring_cost}}, Retrieval {{retrieval_cost}}, Freezing {{freezing_cost}} = TOTAL ~{{total_cost}} per cycle. Storage: {{storage_annual}} per year. Thaw + ICSI later: {{future_cost}}.
next_steps: {{cycle_count}} cycles recommended = {{total_investment}}. Payment: Upfront, EMI available, Multi-cycle packages (10-15% discount), Insurance (check if covered).
reassurance: Yes, it's expensive. But compare to cost of egg donor later ({{donor_cost}}) OR regret of not preserving fertility. Investment in future! ðŸ’š
call_to_action: Financial counseling available. Payment plans. Grants for medical reasons. Decide budget, then design protocol around it.

greeting: {{patient_name}}, you asked about success stories... ðŸ’š

explanation:
Patient A: Froze 18 eggs at age 32, used at 39 â†’ 12 survived, 10 fertilized, 5 embryos, transferred 1 â†’ PREGNANT! 
Patient B: Froze 10 eggs at 34 (cancer), used at 37 â†’ 9 survived, 7 fertilized, 4 embryos â†’ Twins! 
Patient C: Froze 15 eggs at 30, still in storage at 35 â†’ Peace of mind, no regrets!
next_steps: Success depends on: Age at freezing (<35 best), Number of eggs (15-20 ideal), Sperm quality (when using), Embryo transfer luck.
reassurance: Success rates improving yearly! Current: ~60-70% live birth rate per 10 eggs frozen (age <35). Technology gets better with time! ðŸ“ˆ
call_to_action: These are REAL patients from our clinic. You're making the same smart choice they did. Believe in future you!

context: Your partner is worried about egg freezing - common!
explanation: Partner fears: 'Why not try now?', 'Are you not committed?', 'Is it safe?', 'Too expensive!'. Reality: Freezing eggs doesn't mean you WON'T try naturally - it's BACKUP. Many women try naturally first, use frozen eggs if needed. It's insurance, not replacement.
next_steps: Bring partner to next consult. We'll explain together. Show stats. Reassure safety. Discuss timeline (freezing now doesn't delay trying naturally).
reassurance: Couples fight about fertility timing often. Egg freezing actually REDUCES pressure - you can both relax knowing fertility is preserved. Win-win! ðŸ¤
call_to_action: Schedule couple's consultation. Let us mediate the discussion. Many partners become supportive once they understand!

greeting: Hi {{patient_name}}, thank you for your interest in egg freezing at age {{patient_age}}.
context: [HONEST TONE] I want to have a frank conversation about egg freezing at your age.
explanation: [DIRECT] At age {{patient_age}}, egg QUANTITY and QUALITY both decline significantly. Your AMH is {{amh_value}}, which means we might retrieve {{estimated_eggs}} eggs per cycle. But more importantly, at this age, a higher percentage of eggs have chromosomal abnormalities. Even if we freeze {{target_egg_count}} eggs, the success rate per egg is much lower than if you'd frozen them at 32. Realistically, you might need {{adjusted_target}} eggs to have a reasonable chance of one healthy baby. [PAUSE]
next_steps: [OPTIONS] Here are my recommendations: 1) If you're planning to try for a baby in the next 1-2 years, consider doing IVF NOW with fresh eggs and freezing any extra EMBRYOS instead of eggs - embryo freezing has better outcomes. 2) If you're not ready for a baby for 5+ years, egg freezing still makes sense as backup, but set realistic expectations - it's not a guarantee. 3) Consider that donor eggs might be part of your future plan regardless, given age-related quality decline.
reassurance: [EMPATHY] I'm not trying to discourage you - I just want you to make an informed decision with realistic expectations. Every year you wait, egg quality declines further, so if you're going to freeze, better to do it now than wait another year. But understand the limitations at this age.
call_to_action: Think about whether egg freezing makes sense given your timeline and finances. If you proceed, we'll do our best to get good eggs. But also start considering other options like donor eggs as a parallel plan.
contact_info: Let's schedule a follow-up to discuss after you've thought it over. {{clinic_phone}}.
